input:
Marc Lou
@marclou
Â·
12h
My month 1:

- $1B startup idea
- believed I'm Mark Zuckerberg
- printed business cards with "CEO & Founder"
- threatened to sue someone who copied my idea

engagement_feedback: Hook is strongâ€”self-deprecating humor + relatability for founders.
List format is scannable but could tighten phrasing for punchier delivery.
Ending lands well but could amplify with a call-to-action (e.g., 'Whatâ€™s your month 1 story?').
suggested_improvements: Shorten lines 2-4 to 1-2 words each (e.g., 'Zuck 2.0' â†’ 'Mark Zuckerberg 2.0').
Add a closing question to spark replies (e.g., 'Your turnâ€”whatâ€™s your month 1 delusion?').
Consider threading if expanding beyond 280 chars (this post is concise but could tease a follow-up).
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Month 1 of my startup:

- $1B idea
- Mark Zuckerberg 2.0
- 'CEO & Founder' business cards
- Threatened to sue a copycat

Whatâ€™s your month 1 delusion?

input:
How to 10x yourself in 2027:

- Build 10 side projects 
- Read 5 books
- Eat 90% clean food
- Lift weights for 250 days 
- Go to bed at the same time
- No alcohol 

Reply to commit

engagement_feedback: Hook is strong but could be more specific (e.g., 'How to 10x your productivity in 2027').
List items lack urgency or emotional pull; consider adding 'why' for each point.
Call-to-action ('Reply to commit') is clear but could be more engaging (e.g., 'Which one will you start with?').
suggested_improvements: Lead with a more targeted hook (e.g., 'Want to 10x your output in 2027? Do these 6 things:').
Add brief reasoning for each bullet (e.g., 'Build 10 side projects â†’ portfolio + skills').
Replace 'Reply to commit' with a question to spark replies (e.g., 'Which oneâ€™s hardest for you?').
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Want to 10x your output in 2027? Do these 6 things:

- Build 10 side projects â†’ skills + portfolio
- Read 5 books â†’ knowledge edge
- Eat 90% clean â†’ energy boost
- Lift weights 250 days â†’ discipline
- Fixed bedtime â†’ recovery
- No alcohol â†’ mental clarity

Which oneâ€™s hardest for you?

input: 2025 as a solopreneur:   - $2.834M+ in revenue  - Operated at ~91% margins  - Sunset my 2 top products - 134K new followers on LinkedIn  - 45K new followers on ð•  - Traveled domestically 12x  - Traveled internationally 8x  - Threw 7 small masterminds - Exercised 348 days  - Walked 2,460 miles & 6.15M steps  - Lost 8 pounds  - Took my wife to lunch 60x  - Visited 10+ breweries  - Lived abroad for 60 days - Flew our parents on vacation first class  Life came first, business supported it.

grammar: Missing space after colon in opening line: '2025 as a solopreneur:' should have consistent spacing before the dash
clarity: The phrase 'Sunset my 2 top products' may be unclear to some audiences - 'sunset' as a verb isn't universally understood
Mixing business and personal metrics without clear transitions could confuse the narrative flow
structure: Inconsistent spacing between bullet points (some have double spaces, some single)
Business metrics are mixed with personal life metrics without clear categorization
The final sentence works as a conclusion but could be more impactful with better positioning
emoji: No emojis used - could enhance visual appeal and engagement on X platform
Consider adding relevant emojis to break up text and increase scannability

engagement_feedback: Strong opening with impressive revenue numbers - immediately captures attention
The 'Life came first, business supported it.' tagline is powerful and memorable
Vulnerable moment with 'Sunset my 2 top products' shows authenticity
Personal details (wife lunches, parents' first-class trip) create emotional connection
The variety of metrics demonstrates balanced lifestyle, which is aspirational
suggested_improvements: Group metrics by category (Business, Health, Relationships, Travel) for better readability
Add 1-2 relevant emojis to increase visual interest
Consider opening with the punchline ('Life came first...') to hook readers immediately
Replace 'Sunset' with 'Retired' or 'Closed' for broader understanding
Add a call-to-action or question at the end to encourage comments
Fix spacing inconsistencies between bullet points

grammar: Double spaces after 'remember:' and 'harder.' should be single spaces
structure: The bullet points could benefit from better formatting - currently run-on style
Missing line breaks between bullet points reduces readability
The closing sentence feels abrupt and could be more impactful
emoji: No emojis used - could add visual interest and break up text
Consider adding relevant icons for ideas, execution, and consistency

engagement_feedback: Simple, direct message that resonates with target audience
Progressive difficulty scale (easy â†’ hard â†’ harder) creates good rhythm
Short format is perfect for quick consumption on X
The contrast between 'ideas' and 'execution' is a universal pain point

Fix spacing inconsistencies

âš™ï¸ Execution is hard

input: Don't build a "personal brand" in 2026.  Build a life interesting enough for people to pay attention to.

grammar: Double space after '2026.' should be single space
structure: Two-sentence format is simple but could benefit from supporting examples or elaboration
The contrast is clear but feels incomplete - could use more substance
emoji: No emojis used - minimal style works but could add subtle visual interest

engagement_feedback: Strong contrarian hook that challenges conventional wisdom
The phrase 'personal brand' in quotes adds skepticism effectively
Timely reference to 2026 makes it feel current and relevant
The core message is aspirational and philosophically appealing
Short, punchy format is highly shareable
Appeals to people tired of traditional 'personal branding' advice
suggested_improvements: Add 2-3 concrete examples of what 'building an interesting life' looks like
Include a brief story or personal insight to add credibility
Consider adding a question to encourage engagement in comments
Could expand with a thread to provide more value and increase virality
Fix the spacing issue after '2026.'
Optional: Add a subtle emoji to increase visual appeal without losing minimalist vibe
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Don't build a "personal brand" in 2026.

Build a life interesting enough for people to pay attention to.

That means:
â€¢ Taking real risks
â€¢ Having actual experiences
â€¢ Building things that matter
â€¢ Sharing lessons, not just wins
â€¢ Living offline more than online

Authenticity beats strategy every time.

Your life is your content. Make it worth documenting.

input: types of industries paying $10K+ for AI systems (bookmark this): â€¢ medical practices â€¢ real estate companies  â€¢ law firms  â€¢ contractors [/service based] â€¢ accounting [1] how to reach them: â€¢ cold email with a case study â€¢ linkedin direct outreach â€¢ local business events â€¢ paid ads targeting ICP [2] what to sell: â€¢ lead response automation â€¢ AI client intake systems â€¢ document RAG tools â€¢ daily workflow automation serious budgets. zero AI expertise. they're waiting for someone to show up. RT + reply "GUIDE" for the 2-page playbook (must follow)

grammar: Inconsistent capitalization in bullet points (some lowercase, some not)
Missing periods at the end of sections creates choppy flow
The bracketed '[/service based]' format is unclear
clarity: 'ICP' acronym not defined - may confuse some readers (Ideal Customer Profile)
'RAG' acronym not explained - technical jargon (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
The '[1]' and '[2]' numbering system is unclear in purpose
tone: Engagement bait at the end ('RT + reply GUIDE') feels pushy and dated for 2025/2026
structure: Good use of numbered sections but could be more visually distinct
The closing CTA is tacked on rather than integrated smoothly
Could benefit from a stronger hook at the beginning
emoji: Only one emoji (bookmark) - could add more for better visual hierarchy
Section headers could use emojis to improve scannability

engagement_feedback: Actionable, specific information that provides real value
Clear target audience (AI freelancers/agency owners)
Numbered framework makes it easy to follow and implement
Addresses both 'what' and 'how' which is comprehensive
Good use of social proof language ('serious budgets', 'waiting for someone')
Creates urgency and opportunity mindset
suggested_improvements: Define technical acronyms (ICP, RAG) or replace with clearer terms
Add emojis to section headers for better visual hierarchy
Rework the CTA to be less engagement-bait and more value-focused
Add a compelling hook at the start (e.g., revenue potential)
Fix bracket notation and clarify numbering system
Make the structure more visually distinct between sections
Consider adding a brief success story or validation
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
These industries are paying $10K+ for AI systems right now:

ðŸ’° WHO'S BUYING:
â€¢ Medical practices
â€¢ Real estate companies
â€¢ Law firms
â€¢ Service contractors
â€¢ Accounting firms

ðŸ“ HOW TO REACH THEM:
â€¢ Cold email with case studies
â€¢ LinkedIn DMs
â€¢ Local business events
â€¢ Targeted paid ads

ðŸ› ï¸ WHAT TO BUILD:
â€¢ Lead response automation
â€¢ AI client intake systems
â€¢ Document search tools
â€¢ Workflow automation

They have serious budgets but zero AI expertise.

They're literally waiting for someone to help.

Drop a ðŸ¤– if you want my full 2-page implementation guide.

input: you need to write docs seriously. it's a game changer for ai coding here's what actually matters: architecture/decisions â†’ use architecture decision records (ADRs) for every key choice and document the why features/ â†’ keep specs, PRDs, feature docs here. ai can build from them or troubleshoot features fast integrations/ â†’ drop specific api docs. i don't bother with slow global search-just reference straight from here guides/ â†’ best practices, step-by-step how-to's. i even keep guides for ai workflows when building stuff like agents or hooks incidents/ â†’ postmortems go here. super useful to check if an old bug pops back up archive/ â†’ store old projects, docs, finished stuff. never lose the backstory use claude hooks to keep the docs up to date reference docs in your claude.md and most importantly, prompt your agent to use the relevant docs as context makes all the difference â™¥ï¸

grammar: Missing capitalization at sentence starts throughout
Run-on sentences need better punctuation
Inconsistent use of periods at end of bullet points
clarity: The folder structure notation (architecture/, features/) isn't immediately clear
'PRDs' acronym not defined (Product Requirements Documents)
'claude.md' reference may confuse readers unfamiliar with the file
The flow jumps between concepts without clear transitions
structure: Wall of text format reduces readability significantly
No clear visual hierarchy or section breaks
The folder structure could be formatted as a visual tree
Opening hook gets lost in the details
emoji: Only one emoji at the very end - needs more throughout for visual breaks
Folder/category icons would significantly improve scannability

engagement_feedback: Highly valuable technical content for AI developers
Specific, actionable folder structure that can be implemented immediately
Personal touch ('i don't bother', 'i even keep') makes it relatable
Addresses a real pain point in AI-assisted development
The 'game changer' claim in the hook creates curiosity
suggested_improvements: Add proper capitalization and punctuation for professionalism
Break up text with clear section headers and line breaks
Add emojis to each folder category for visual hierarchy
Define acronyms or use more accessible language
Create a visual tree structure for the folder system
Add a concrete example or before/after scenario
Include a CTA or question to drive engagement
Lead with the benefit more strongly
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Documentation is the secret to 10x better AI coding.

Here's my exact folder structure that makes Claude actually useful:

ðŸ“ architecture/
â†’ ADRs for every major decision
â†’ Document the WHY, not just the what

âœ¨ features/
â†’ Specs, PRDs, feature docs
â†’ AI builds straight from these

ðŸ”Œ integrations/
â†’ API docs for quick reference
â†’ No more slow global searches

ðŸ“š guides/
â†’ Best practices & how-to's
â†’ AI workflow templates

ðŸš¨ incidents/
â†’ Postmortems
â†’ Catch recurring bugs instantly

ðŸ“¦ archive/
â†’ Old projects & context
â†’ Never lose the backstory

Pro tip: Reference these docs in your claude.md file. Then prompt your agent to use them as context.

Makes all the difference. â™¥ï¸

What's your doc structure look like?

input: our little bootstrapped SaaS just crossed $61k MRR. it took 53 days. We used no paid ads, no cold outbound. everyone on X is asking how we get customers so here it is... hope this helps someone:

grammar: Missing capitalization at sentence starts ('it took', 'everyone on X')
Inconsistent capitalization of 'We' mid-sentence
clarity: Post appears incomplete - ends with a cliffhanger without the actual strategy
The '53 days' timeframe needs context - 53 days from launch? From $0?

suggested_improvements: Add examples of each path to make it more concrete
Include emojis to visually separate the two options

Add a question to encourage discussion and engagement
Consider explaining why this dichotomy exists
ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Hard truth about indie hacking:

ðŸ‘¥ If you want followers:
â†’ Build for indie hackers

ðŸ’° If you want revenue:
â†’ Build for businesses

Why? Indie hackers love sharing and engaging with tools made for them. But they're price-sensitive and have limited budgets.

Businesses have real budgets. They'll pay $500/month for something that saves them time.

You can do both. Just know which goal you're optimizing for.

What are you building for?

input: Don't build a "personal brand" in 2026.  Build a life interesting enough for people to pay attention to.

Consider adding a question to encourage engagement in comments

ideal_output.rewritten_post:
Don't build a "personal brand" in 2026.

Build a life interesting enough for people to pay attention to.

That means:
â€¢ Taking real risks
â€¢ Having actual experiences
â€¢ Building things that matter
â€¢ Sharing lessons, not just wins
â€¢ Living offline more than online

Authenticity beats strategy every time.

Your life is your content. Make it worth documenting.
